newsitem.title: USA: U.S. 30-year bond seen rising to 7.25 pct soon.
newsitem.headline: U.S. 30-year bond seen rising to 7.25 pct soon.

text.p: Barring an extremely weak March employment report on Friday, the days of the 30-year U.S. Treasury bond yielding below 7.0 percent are behind us for the foreseeable future, technical analysts said.
Rather, they added, it appears as if the bond -- at 7.10 percent on Tuesday afternoon -- is marching toward 7.25 percent, then higher, to yields not seen in about two years.
"We are in the early stages of a long-term bear market," said Richard Suttmeier, president and technical trader at Global Market Consultants. "People aren't realizing that yet.
"People are still under the assumption that we are still in a bull market and that dips are meant to buy," Suttmeier said.
Technical analysts noted that the market was in pretty bad shape, with Treasuries deemed oversold.
Until Friday's jobs data, though, the bond was seen sticking to a 7.07- to 7.12-percent range.
"If we get a strong number, we would test the old highs" of 7.20 to 7.25 percent, said John "Rocket" Spinello, government securities strategist and managing director of Merrill Lynch & Co Inc.
"If we get friendly, non-farm payrolls, less than a 220,000 rise and no bad wages, I think we could stage a bit of a rally" back near 7.0 percent, Spinello said.
Still, he acknowledged, the trend is "to higher yields."
Nonfarm payrolls are expected to have grown by 182,000 in March, with the unemployment rate dipping to 5.2 percent and average hourly earnings up 0.4 percent, according to a Reuters poll.
Should bond yields rise to 7.25 percent, it would be the highest level since the close of business on May 3, 1995, which at that time, marked an 11-month low.

The bellwether yield had been as high as 7.15 percent on a closing basis on September 6, and 7.19 percent on July 8. On Tuesday morning, the bond climbed as high as 7.13 percent -- but only for a brief moment.
"It's safe to say that we are in a nine-month trading range: July to April," Merrill's Spinello added.
But the odds of breaking out of that range sometime soon look good.
Ronald Daino, technical trader at Smith Barney Inc, put the chance of a 7.25 percent bond at 40 percent, with a 30 percent shot at it rising to 7.50 to 7.60 percent.
He noted that there was no specific time period. "The direction is the important thing," Daino said.
Suttmeier, however, predicted that the bond yield would jump to 7.34 percent in three to five weeks.
"If payrolls are negative (for the market) we'll get to 7.34 percent sooner rather than later," he said, noting that a friendly report would delay reaching that target somewhat.
As for the rest of the curve, technicans see the 10-year note rising to 7.09 percent when the bond reaches 7.25 percent, the five-year note at 6.90 percent and the two-year at 6.50 percent.
"The key level to hold is 6.76 percent on the two-year note in the longer term," Suttmeier said. "If that ever gives way, the market will anticipate more than a 6.0 percent federal funds rate."
(( -- N.A. Treasury Desk, 212-859-1867 ))
